There is a easy solution. Turn 80% of the sea in protected Areas where all extracting of natural resources is banned and the ban is enforced.
Protected Areas are selected by habitat, spawning ground and travel routes of fishes.

Why not just let economics self-regulate it? Fish populations fall = harder to catch more so prices will rise to where most can't afford it until demand drops and populations recover. In most places you can't just walk into a store and buy $1000 jars of beluga caviar, same can apply to plain tuna or the cod used to make fish sticks.

According to the Cousteau Foundation (well last time I read about it) most fisheries are subsidized. In democracies they're bought vote blocks; in authoritarian states it looks to be a way of projecting power (by creating figures that show that the leadership is winning the race to kill everything, at home, and by having resources out on the seas useful to the navy - but I'm only guessing - there has to be some reasonable explanation.)

According to the same foundation, there aren't enough "resources" (you know: the rent all other living creatures have to pay us for the privilege of living) in the Ocean to compare significantly to land based "resources" (thing have to pay us rent for their right to breathe on land, too). The seas aren't going to "feed the masses" as the spin version of the story goes.

Also according to the same foundation, fisheries that are "regulated" tend to be "limited" to extracting the absolute maximum the relevant ecosystem can produce, with no margin of safety built in. They're restricted to the very borderline between collapse and survival to some degree. If something goes wrong, "regulated" fisheries have a tendency to collapse. As in the population of the prey species gets knocked down so hard it never gets back up again.

If you add that all up, if we were moral Human Beings, instead of locusts with human faces that just know how to eat eat eat, what we'd do is turn the entire Ocean into an international nature reserve. Not a "resource" to squeeze until it breaks, but something we naturally are the custodians of: Life.

We live pointless existences (at least on the grand scale of things - at small scales, we obviously mean something). We run on a hamster wheel, round and round, urgently rushing to nowhere. But we could invent a natural purpose for ourselves. A nice simple purpose, too. Instead of being the molesters of Life, we could set ourselves up as its parents. We could look after Earth life, and give it a future. There's plenty of time to do this, and it's obviously the best cause we could exist for.

So then why not begin educating ourselves in what this entails, in the details, by becoming so civilized that we stop eating the "free stuff in the sea" as if we were insects, and instead look after it, knowing its worth, as human beings. We could become human beings. When we're sucking the life out of the sea the way we do, we're not being human. We're not being what the Human Being could be, or should be. We make our very selves worthless. And what's the point of having lots of More when your very self is worth nothing (or even less than nothing - something the world would be better off without).

Ban fishing, and these problems become much simpler to deal with. And our "garden" will get much more beautiful as an automatic byproduct.
better and easy idea is to just BAN all fishing in natural water bodies, Ask companies & farmers to cultivate own fish in artificial ponds and only sell them.

0:33 ". . . and everyone needs to play by the rules."
SNORTS Good frikken luck with that. Seems pretty naiive to me.

1. Tracking an RFID chip or QR code on a blockchain doesn't help. It simply means the RFID or QR can be replaced and now you're faithfully tracking the wrong thing. This is known as the "oracle" problem as you have a single point of truth (the ID/code) linking the real world thing to the data being tracked.
2. Not all blockchains are energy intensive.
3. Blockchains use energy for security. Therefore, blockchains that aren't energy intensive (i.e. every blockchain other than Bitcoin) aren't secure, and therefore useless at doing the intended task of being an immutable source of truth.
4. "Energy intensive" does not mean "ecologically negative". The energy spent on Bitcoin is an ecological positive by encouraging energy efficient production, enabling smoother energy supply, and reducing the reliance on other more wasteful economic energy uses.

Yes but, clearly, far too many DON'T play by the rules. Relying on the end point of an urban, developed country fish retailer  to regulate is is pointless. What % of the world catch DOESNT end up like this?

Way overblown on the energy issue. The 2 main crypto block chains use proof of work which is energy intense. Ethereum is about to switch to proof of stake where instead of computations it will be locked eth coins used as stake. Almost no energy. Plus the main blockchain company in this logistics field is VeChain and it uses proof of authority which again, is not algorithms solved by a computer. Bit coin blockchain is not going to be used for logistics, and proof of work is old school now. Takes too much energy. Most are proof of stake...

I don't think Blockchains are inherently energy intensive. After all, they are simply a chain of blocks where the las block contains a cryptographic hash of the previous one, recursively. So, as long as the Blockchain ()or even just the hashes) is published openly, it's impossible to manipulate.

The energy intensive part is part of the decentralized system, which isn't really an issue in the case, because the UN or whoever would easily host this Blockchain, which could be mirrored by anyone else, with guaranteed data integrity

Crypto evangelists love to talk about how blockchains are unhackable but ignore the fact that almost all fraud happens because an authorised user deliberately inputs false information into the system, i.e. a fishing boat lying about their catch. The problem is that fishermen like those from China DON'T FOLLOW THE RULES, nor do they seem to care if they are monitored as they will just move to somewhere that monitoring doesn't exist. On top of all of this, the quantities that they take are so vast that fisheries will have completely collapsed by the time someone can prove what they are doing.  If more of the resources that are going into monitoring the rule-followers were used to control the rule breakers and avoiders, we may still have fish around in the future. Eh I think the major reason people think blockchain solutions are energy intensive is because some cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Ethereum, etc) use "Proof-of-Work" mining to keep the chain moving and is used to reward miners. This often requires LOTS of power to solve cryptographic puzzles as such currencies are designed to only produce a set number per day, and increase in difficulty as more people mine it to keep the numbers the same day-to-day. However there are many kinds of blockchains that run on other methods, and only require a few dozen/hundred nodes running regular desktop hardware
